@cjmctague  are you squashing and force pushing?  If so we usually avoid this while code review is in progress, in favor of only appending commits.  This makes it easier for the reviewer to see whats changed.  After the code review is finished we may squash it into one commit.

I took a look at it.  The implementation of Bytes.hashCode() seems incorrect.  Seems like it would only hash one byte effectively?  I was thinking we could call Arrays.hashCode() on the byte array, but I see that the array is not available.  This got me thinking about moving all of the implementation of MutableBytes in Bytes and removing MutableBytes.  Also I realized that #743 needed to be done.  For now, you could drop the hashCode method from Bytes and introduce it in MutableBytes (using Arrays.hashCode).
I am going to work on this for 1.0

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4056140/maven-resource-filtering-implications-of-the-symbol-in-resource-files
:+1: (interesting note about new GitHub review stuffs.... can't :+1: a previous approval, and can't add an approval to an already merged PR).

``` bash
function checkFile {
  local file; file=$1
  echo '='
  echo "$file"
  gpg2 --verify "${file}".asc "$file"
  for hash in md5 sha1; do
    ${hash}sum -c <(echo "$(cat "${file}.${hash}") *$file")
  done
}
export -f checkFile
find . -type f -regex '.*\.\(pom\|jar\|gz\)' -exec bash -c 'checkFile $0' {} \;
```

Maybe simpler, and leaves some MD5SUM, SHA1SUM files around to manually check later:

``` bash
function checkFile {
  echo '='
  echo "$1"
  gpg2 --verify "$1".asc "$1"
  echo "$(cat "$1".md5) *$1" >> MD5SUM
  echo "$(cat "$1".sha1) *$1" >> SHA1SUM
}
export -f checkFile
rm MD5SUM SHA1SUM
#find . -type f -name '*.asc' -exec bash -c 'checkFile "$(dirname "$0")/$(basename "$0" .asc)"' {} \;
find . -type f -regex '.*\.\(pom\|jar\|gz\)' -exec bash -c 'checkFile "$0"' {} \;
md5sum --quiet -c MD5SUM
sha1sum --quiet -c SHA1SUM
```

The commented out find command is a little more comprehensive... it'll check all files with a detached gpg signature. The original one only checks for `pom`, `jar`, and `gz` files, and that may not catch everything.
Instead of putting this info in the email, we should have the email point to web page with information on how to download and verify the release.

Check out the `Validating a Release` section of the following page.

http://kylin.apache.org/development/howto_release.html
@ctubbsii  can this be closed?
This was done
Yes. Done.
So, this was just a test bug, not a problem with collisions? That's a relief.

> So, this was just a test bug, not a problem with collisions? That's a relief.

I don't have positive confirmation of that.  Looking at the code I could see that the logic for waiting was wrong, so maybe sometimes the test did not wait long enough.

In the place where the test failed it was attempting to verify the Fluo GC iterator worked correctly.  So if there is a problem, its with garbage collection not cleaning up everything it should.  The earlier part of the test that checks transactions worked correctly w/ collisions did not fail.

Another possible solution to this problem, would be to add an async commit.  This would allow transactions to get a callback when a commit completes.  This offer similar functionality as adding a post commit callback to the loader interface.  This would avoid having a thread wait for commit and allow many transactions to be working their way through the commit process.

I described a solution without describing the problem very well.  The problem this issue is trying to solve is getting good throughput from a source of continuous information that needs feedback on when that information was successfully processed by Fluo.  The LoaderExecutor gives good throughput for committing transactions, but lacks the feedback mechanism.

I was thinking about how to solve  this w/ the current 1.0.0 release.  One way would be to process batches with the loader executor.  For example process 10,000 transactions with the LoaderExecutor and then shut the LoaderExecutor down.  After its shut down, then feedback can be given to the information source that all 10,000 transactions completed.
May want to document the issues with logback vs log4j when running in Yarn, with some background on this issue.
We also need to document that it would be best if observers used slf4j when doing their own logging.  That could be a new issue/PR
Need to make sure it logs something for a scan that returns nothing

Could log scanned data at a more specific level that could be turned off. Something like `fluo.tx.scan` which could be suppressed.  A single line summary about scanned data could be logged at `fluo.tx` level.

Accumulo's client code has suffered from excessive caching of objects globally/statically in the JVM, all outside the user's control. If a caching feature is introduced, the user should have control over the size and lifecycle of the cache, to learn from Accumulo's lessons.

Of the options, I think the short-lived cache is most appealing. But, if it's user-provided, they could selectively re-use the same cache for many operations.
In #804 I did some very narrow caching.  This caching is only at a per transaction level and in some cases only per a transactions operation.

> Very cool. Did you test this out by adding a log4j import and seeing if the build failed?

Yeah  I did.  I also tried using non public API stuff from Accumulo to make sure the checks from the parent were still working.   I also ran `mvn help:effective-pom` in `modules/core` and `modules/api` .  Running that maven command I could see that the checkstyle config in parent and child were merged properly.
